bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Alfred Bertram Gurthrie (1901-1991) was born in Bedford, Indiana in the year 1901 to Alfred B. and June Thomas Guthrie. The Guthrie family moved shortly after Alfred Jr.'s birth to their more permanent home in Choteau, Montana, where Guthrie began his education. In 1919 he was accepted at the University of Washington and later transferred to the University of Montana, where he would go on to graduate with honors in 1923. Following his graduation, Gurthrie worked a number of odd jobs before settling down in a career with theLexington Leader newspaper, where he remained for the next 21 years as a reporter, editor, and editorial writer. From 1947-1952 Guthrie worked as a creative writing professor at the University of Kentucky. In 1947 he published his novel The Big Sky, and in 1949 a continuation of the story was published in The Way West. This second novel would go on to win a Pulitzer Prize for fiction. By the time of his death in 1991, Guthrie had written a total of: six novels, one book of essays, one children's book, one book of poems, and five mystery novels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The A. B. Guthrie, Jr. papers (dated 1891-1985, undated; 7.23 cubic feet; 7 boxes) primarily comprise manuscripts, copies, personal correspondence, and edits of works written by the novelist Alfred Bertram Guthrie, Jr. The collection includes original manuscripts, galley proofs, and revised copies of his work.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The physical rights to the materials in this collection are held by the University of Kentucky Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Arfive (1971) series, 1970, undated, the draft manuscript and revisions of the book, a part of A.B. Guthrie's epic of the west book series. The plot revolves around the relationship of new high school principal and a rancher set in a small Montana town. The book was first published in January 1, 1971 by Houghton Mifflin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bent's Fort (unpublished screenplay) series, 1958-1960, undated, includes the script for A.B. Guthrie's adaptation of Bent's Fork by David Lavender. It is a historical account of the Arkansas River, Colorado nineteenth century private fort. Guthrie wrote the script while working in Hollywood in the 1950's. The script never entered into production.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Big It and Other Stories (1960) series, undated, includes the manuscript and galley proofs of A.B. Guthrie's first collection of short stories about life on the frontier. It was first published in 1960 by Hought Mifflin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Big Sky (1947) series, 1891-1952, undated, includes the book's manuscript and printing proofs, as well as, Guthrie's research, correspondence, and collection of the book's reviews. The Big Sky is Guthrie's first major novel, published in 1947 by William Sloane Associates. The story follows a young man's life as a Mountain Man in Kentucky, Missouri, and along the Missouri River, beginning in the 1830's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Blue Hen's Chick (1965) sesries, 1965, contains the publisher's manuscript for A.B. Guthrie's autobiography. Guthrie's memoir recounts his youth growing up in Montana during the early twentieth century and his career as a writer. The autobiography was first published in 1965 by McGraw-Hill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fair Land, Fair Land (1982), undated, series the book's manuscripts, proof, and revisions. Fair Land, Fair Land released in 1982 by Houghton Mifflin Company, was the last published book in Guthrie's six book series known as the epic of the west novels by Guthrie. It follows the character, Dick Summers, as he return travels the Oregon Trail during the mid 1800's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Genuine Article (1977) series, undated, contains the book's manuscripts, proofs, and revisions. The story is a double murder mystery, set in Montana, features Sheriff Chick Charleston as he solves the crime.The Genuine Article was first published in 1977 by Houghton Mifflin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Last Valley (1975), undated, comprise the novel's manuscripts, proofs, and revisions. The Last Valley is the final book of the epic of the west series that began with The Big Sky. It is the final book because time period ranges between early 1900 thru the post WWII years, but it was the fifth of six books published. It focuses on the societal and landscape changes in Montana in the western United States during the the beginning of the twentieth century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Murders at Moon Dance (1943) series contains the manuscripts and jacket cover for the novel published by It is the first cross between a traditional Western and a murder mystery published written by A.B. Guthrie and published by E.P. Dutton, New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The No Second Wind (1980) series contains the manuscripts and proofs of the book by A.B. Guthrie, Jr. It is the third western mystery novel by Guthrie to feature Sheriff Chick Charleston. It was published by Houghton Mifflin in 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Once Upon a Pond (1973) series contains the manuscript and revisions of the second children's book by A.B. Guthrie, Jr. It features Maggie Magpie, Mephitis Skunk, Busy Beaver, and the other animal inhabitants of Pond Placid. The book was orginally published by Mountain Press Publishing Company and illustrated by Carol B. Guthrie.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Playing Catch-Up (1985) series contains the publisher's manuscript and proof for the westen mystery novel by A.B. Gutrie. The plot centers around a murder at a Montana brothel solved by Sheriff Chick Charleston. The book was first published by Houghton Mifflin in 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The These Thousand Hills (1956) series comprises manuscripts, proofs, and revision of the novel. It is the fourth story in western epic series by A.B. Guthrie, Jr. The focuses on life in the west, particulary Montana during the mid 1800's. These Thousand Hills was orignally published in 1956 by Houghton Mifflin Company.
